name: Boeing 777-200
description: The Boeing 777-200 is the original variant of the 777 family, a long-range wide-body twin-engine airliner. First delivered in 1995, it was the first commercial aircraft designed entirely by computer. The 777-200 typically seats 300-314 passengers in a three-class configuration and features the largest diameter turbofan engines of any aircraft. It introduced fly-by-wire flight controls to Boeing's commercial lineup.

zones.name: Cockpit
zones.description: The 777 flight deck features a state-of-the-art glass cockpit with six large flat-panel LCD displays, fly-by-wire controls, and a fully integrated avionics suite. It was the first Boeing aircraft with a fly-by-wire flight control system.

zones.name: Forward Galley
zones.description: The forward galley serves first and business class passengers, with larger capacity for premium meal service.

zones.name: Forward Lavatory
zones.description: Forward lavatories located near the first/business class cabin, typically more spacious than economy lavatories.

zones.name: Forward Vestibule
zones.description: The forward entry vestibule at door 1L/1R. The wide-body doors accommodate higher passenger flow during boarding.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left window and middle seats in the forward cabin, typically configured as first or business class in a 2-abreast section. The 777's wide fuselage allows spacious premium seating along the left side.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the forward cabin, one of the twin aisles that define the wide-body 777 cabin layout. Provides access between the forward vestibule and the mid cabin.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the forward cabin between the twin aisles. In first class, this section typically has a 2-abreast center configuration with direct aisle access from both sides.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the forward cabin, providing a second path through the premium class section for efficient passenger movement.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right window and middle seats in the forward cabin, mirroring the left side premium class configuration with views through the 777's large cabin windows.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section in the mid cabin, typically configured as 3-abreast economy or premium economy seating along the port side of the aircraft over the wing.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the mid cabin section, running over the wing box area. One of two parallel aisles serving the economy class section.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the mid cabin between the twin aisles, typically configured as 3-abreast in a 3-3-3 economy layout. The center section has no window access but offers proximity to both aisles.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the mid cabin, providing the second path through the economy section for service carts and passenger movement.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section in the mid cabin, configured as 3-abreast economy seating along the starboard side with window views over the right wing.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section in the aft cabin, configured as 3-abreast economy seating. Aft passengers are nearest to the rear galleys and lavatories.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the aft cabin, connecting the mid cabin to the aft vestibule and rear service areas.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the aft cabin between the twin aisles. The last rows of the center section may have limited recline due to the aft bulkhead.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the aft cabin, providing access to the rear boarding doors and aft service areas.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section in the aft cabin, mirroring the left side economy configuration. Window seats here offer views of the aft fuselage and horizontal stabilizer.

zones.name: Aft Vestibule
zones.description: The aft entry vestibule with the rear boarding doors, used for dual-door boarding on wide-body operations.

zones.name: Aft Galley
zones.description: The aft galley serves the economy cabin. The wide-body configuration allows for significantly more galley capacity than narrow-body aircraft.

zones.name: Aft Lavatory
zones.description: Multiple aft lavatories serving the economy cabin, typically 4-5 units across the rear of the aircraft.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Hold
zones.description: The forward lower-deck cargo hold beneath the forward cabin, accommodating LD3 containers side by side in the wide-body fuselage. Heated and pressurized for temperature-sensitive cargo and live animals.

zones.name: Aft Cargo Hold
zones.description: The aft lower-deck cargo hold beneath the mid and aft cabins, providing the largest cargo volume on the aircraft. Accommodates LD3 containers and bulk freight with powered cargo handling systems.

zones.name: Bulk Cargo Hold
zones.description: The bulk cargo compartment aft of the main cargo holds, used for loose-loaded baggage and small freight items that do not require containerization.

zones.name: Cargo Access
zones.description: The forward cargo access passage connecting the main deck to the lower cargo holds, used by ground crew during loading operations.

zones.name: Nose
zones.description: The nose section with the large weather radar antenna, radome, and forward avionics bay.

zones.name: Forward Fuselage
zones.description: The forward lower fuselage contains the forward cargo hold, large enough for LD3 containers in a wide-body configuration.

zones.name: Mid Fuselage
zones.description: The center lower fuselage with the wing box, center fuel tank, and main gear wheel wells. The 777's wing box is one of the largest composite structures in commercial aviation.

zones.name: Aft Fuselage
zones.description: The aft lower fuselage with the rear cargo hold and bulk cargo compartment. Houses the aft equipment bay.

zones.name: Tail
zones.description: The tail section with APU and empennage structures. The 777's tail is proportionally larger than the 737 due to the aircraft's greater size.

zones.name: Left Wing
zones.description: The port wing spans 30.4 meters from centerline with a supercritical airfoil profile. It contains integral fuel tanks and features folding wingtips on some variants.

zones.name: Right Wing
zones.description: The starboard wing is identical to the port wing, with fuel tanks, ailerons, flaperons, slats, and spoilers.

zones.name: Left Engine
zones.description: The left GE90-94B engine produces 94,000 lbs of thrust. The GE90 has a 128-inch fan diameter, the largest in aviation at the time of its introduction.

zones.name: Right Engine
zones.description: The right GE90-94B engine, identical to the left. The massive nacelle diameter is larger than the fuselage of a 737.

zones.name: Left Main Gear
zones.description: The left main landing gear is a six-wheel bogie unit, one of the largest in commercial aviation. It retracts inward into the fuselage belly.

zones.name: Right Main Gear
zones.description: The right main gear is a six-wheel bogie identical to the left unit, together supporting the 777's maximum takeoff weight of up to 247,200 kg.

zones.name: Nose Gear
zones.description: The steerable nose gear with dual wheels, retracting forward. Larger than the 737 nose gear to support the 777's greater weight.

zones.name: Vertical Stabilizer
zones.description: The vertical stabilizer is 9.8 meters tall, providing directional stability for the large twin-engine aircraft.

zones.name: Horizontal Stabilizer
zones.description: The trimmable horizontal stabilizer spans approximately 21.3 meters and provides pitch stability for the aircraft.

zones.name: APU
zones.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU in the tail cone provides 225 kVA of electrical power for ground operations.

components.name: Captain's Control Column
components.description: The captain's control column with yoke. Unlike the 737, the 777's fly-by-wire system means the yoke sends electronic signals rather than mechanical inputs to the control surfaces.
components.interactionText: Grasp the captain's yoke. The 777's fly-by-wire system converts yoke movements to electronic signals processed by the Primary Flight Computers.

components.name: First Officer's Control Column
components.description: The first officer's fly-by-wire control column, electronically linked to the captain's controls.
components.interactionText: The first officer's yoke is electronically linked via the fly-by-wire system, with independent authority.

components.name: Throttle Quadrant
components.description: The center pedestal with two thrust levers for the GE90-94B engines. Includes autothrottle servo motors for automated thrust management.
components.interactionText: Advance the thrust levers to command the GE90 engines. The autothrottle system manages thrust automatically in most flight phases.

components.name: Rudder Pedals
components.description: Rudder pedal assemblies for both pilots. The 777's fly-by-wire rudder system provides variable ratio rudder authority based on airspeed.
components.interactionText: Press left or right pedal for yaw control. The fly-by-wire system automatically limits rudder authority at higher speeds.

components.name: Primary Flight Display (PFD)
components.description: Large-format PFD with attitude, airspeed, altitude, heading, and flight mode information on an LCD panel.
components.interactionText: The large PFD displays attitude, speeds, altitude, and flight mode annunciations on a high-resolution LCD.

components.name: Navigation Display (ND)
components.description: The Navigation Display showing route, traffic, terrain, and weather information with selectable range and modes.
components.interactionText: View the navigation display with TCAS traffic, EGPWS terrain, weather overlay, and flight plan route.

components.name: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System
components.description: The EICAS displays engine parameters for both GE90 engines and provides crew alerts on dual screens.
components.interactionText: Monitor the GE90 engine parameters: N1, N2, N3, EGT, fuel flow, oil pressure and temperature on the upper EICAS display.

components.name: Overhead Panel
components.description: The overhead systems panel controlling electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic, pressurization, and fire protection for the larger 777 systems.
components.interactionText: The 777 overhead panel has systems controls organized by ATA chapter, with dark cockpit philosophy for normal operations.

components.name: Mode Control Panel (MCP)
components.description: The autopilot and autothrottle interface panel with speed, heading, altitude, and vertical speed selectors.
components.interactionText: Set autopilot targets for speed, heading, altitude, and vertical speed. The 777 MCP supports LNAV, VNAV, and autoland modes.

components.name: Flight Management Computer (FMC)
components.description: The triple-redundant FMC with CDU interface for flight planning and performance management on the 777's long-range missions.
components.interactionText: Program routes spanning continents on the FMC. The 777's FMC handles complex oceanic and ETOPS routing.

components.name: Forward Left Entry Door (1L)
components.description: The main wide-body boarding door, significantly larger than narrow-body doors to accommodate higher passenger volume.
components.interactionText: The wide-body entry door with dual-lane evacuation slide. Door assist mechanisms help crew operate the heavy door.

components.name: Aft Left Entry Door (4L)
components.description: The aft left entry door for rear boarding. The 777 has multiple door pairs along the fuselage for efficient evacuation.
components.interactionText: The aft wide-body door enables rapid evacuation. All 777 doors meet the 90-second evacuation certification requirement.

components.name: Forward Galley Unit
components.description: The premium class forward galley with extensive meal preparation facilities for first and business class service.
components.interactionText: The wide-body forward galley accommodates full meal service with multiple ovens, chillers, and beverage stations.

components.name: Aft Galley Unit
components.description: The aft economy galley, larger than narrow-body galleys to serve the 777's higher passenger count.
components.interactionText: The aft galley serves over 200 economy passengers with multiple cart positions and preparation stations.

components.name: Overhead Storage Bins
components.description: Wide-body overhead bins on both sides and center of the cabin, accommodating bags for the 9 or 10 abreast seating.
components.interactionText: The 777 has three rows of overhead bins: left, center, and right, providing ample storage for wide-body passenger counts.

components.name: Row 1 First Class Seats
components.description: The first row of first class seats, typically configured as spacious suites in a 1-2-1 layout with direct aisle access.
components.interactionText: Examine the first class suite with lie-flat bed, personal entertainment screen, privacy partition, and premium amenities.

components.name: Forward Cabin Business Class Seats
components.description: Business class seats in a 2-3-2 configuration in the forward cabin. These lie-flat seats offer direct aisle access from window positions and feature personal entertainment screens, power outlets, and adjustable privacy dividers.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin business class seat. The 2-3-2 layout gives most passengers direct aisle access. Adjust the lie-flat mechanism, check the personal entertainment screen, and find the power outlet in the center console.

components.name: Mid Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy class seats in the mid cabin in a 3-3-3 configuration, typical for the 777-200. The wide-body fuselage allows nine-abreast seating with two aisles. Seat pitch is typically 31-32 inches. Each seat has a personal seatback entertainment screen.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin economy seat. The twin-aisle 3-3-3 layout is spacious for economy class. Each seat has a personal entertainment screen, USB charging port, and adjustable headrest. The wide cabin gives a more open feeling than narrow-body aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the aft cabin section of the 777-200. The rear of the aircraft may experience more motion in turbulence. Last-row seats often have limited recline. Aft passengers are closest to the rear galleys and lavatories.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft economy seat. You are in the rear section of this wide-body aircraft. The twin aisles allow efficient boarding and deplaning. Check the seatback screen, tray table, and life vest under the seat.

components.name: Passenger Cabin Window
components.description: The 777 cabin windows are larger than the 737's, measuring approximately 15 inches tall, providing a better view for passengers.
components.interactionText: Look through the larger 777 cabin window. The triple-layer construction includes a structural outer pane, inner pane, and scratch pane.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the forward cabin. The 777's three-row bin system provides left, center, and right bins across the wide cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin above the forward cabin seats. The wide-body bins are deeper than narrow-body bins, accommodating larger carry-on bags.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the forward cabin, mirroring the left side configuration.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the forward cabin. Premium class bins may have additional space due to lower passenger density.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the mid cabin over the wing section.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the mid cabin. These bins serve the economy class passengers seated along the port side.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the mid cabin, mirroring the left side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the mid cabin. The starboard bins serve passengers on the right side of the aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the aft economy cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the aft cabin. Bins in the rear section fill up last during boarding.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the aft economy cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the aft cabin. The last overhead bins before the aft vestibule and galley areas.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the forward cabin, offering views of the airport terminal during boarding or the sky at cruise altitude.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward cabin left window. In first or business class, the larger window spacing gives premium passengers a generous view of the world below.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the forward cabin, providing views from the starboard side of the aircraft.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward cabin right window. The 777's windows are approximately 15 inches tall, noticeably larger than narrow-body aircraft windows.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the mid cabin, positioned over the wing with views of the engine and leading edge slats.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin left window over the wing. You can see the left GE90 engine nacelle, the leading edge slats, and the wing fuel vents.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the mid cabin, offering views over the starboard wing and engine.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin right window. The right GE90 engine and wing are visible, along with the spoiler panels on the wing upper surface.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the aft cabin, offering views of the wing trailing edge and the ground below.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin left window. You can see the trailing edge of the wing, the flap track fairings, and the ground far below.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the aft cabin, with views aft toward the horizontal stabilizer.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin right window. Looking aft, you can see the horizontal stabilizer and the sky stretching to the horizon.

components.name: Forward Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats in the forward cabin with significantly more legroom due to the overwing emergency exit positioning. Passengers seated here must be able to assist in an evacuation.
components.interactionText: Sit in the forward exit row seat. Notice the extra legroom and the emergency exit door beside you. Read the special safety briefing card for exit row passengers.

components.name: Forward Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the forward business class cabin with panoramic views through the 777's large cabin windows. The window seat offers privacy from the aisle and a wall to lean against.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin window seat. The 777's larger windows give you a wide view of the clouds and terrain below. Adjust the window shade and settle into the premium seat.

components.name: Forward Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the forward business class cabin, positioned between the twin aisles with easy access to both sides of the aircraft.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin center seat between the aisles. In business class, center seats often feature privacy partitions and direct aisle access from both sides.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats at the overwing emergency exits in the mid cabin. These seats have the most legroom in economy class and are positioned adjacent to the Type III overwing exits.
components.interactionText: Sit in the overwing exit row. You have several extra inches of legroom. The emergency exit hatch is beside you. Review the exit row briefing card carefully.

components.name: Mid Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the mid cabin economy section, positioned over the wing with views of the engine and flight control surfaces.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin window seat over the wing. Watch the flaps and slats deploy during approach. The GE90 engine is visible forward on the wing.

components.name: Mid Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the mid cabin economy class. In the 3-3-3 configuration, the center seat has aisle access from both sides but no window view.
components.interactionText: Sit in a center economy seat. While there is no window, you have convenient access to both aisles. The personal seatback screen provides entertainment for the flight.

components.name: Aft Cabin Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats in the aft cabin near the rear emergency exits, offering extra legroom and responsibility for assisting with evacuation if needed.
components.interactionText: Sit in the aft exit row with extra legroom. The emergency exit is within arm's reach. Familiarize yourself with the exit operation procedure on the briefing card.

components.name: Aft Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the aft economy cabin. From here, passengers can see the wing trailing edge and the ground below, with the horizontal stabilizer visible aft.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin window seat. Looking out, you can see the trailing edge of the wing and the flap track fairings. The ground scrolls by far below.

components.name: Last Row Economy Seat
components.description: The very last row of economy seats before the aft bulkhead. These seats have limited recline but are closest to the rear lavatories and galleys.
components.interactionText: Sit in the last row of economy. The seat recline is limited by the bulkhead behind you, but you are steps from the lavatories and galley for snack runs.

components.name: Forward Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 unit load devices stacked in the forward cargo hold. The 777's wide-body cross-section accommodates LD3 containers two abreast on the lower deck.
components.interactionText: Examine the LD3 cargo containers in the forward hold. Each aluminum container holds up to 1,588 kg and is designed to fit the curved lower fuselage contour.

components.name: Forward Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: The cargo restraint net system in the forward hold, securing LD3 containers and preventing cargo shift during flight maneuvers and turbulence.
components.interactionText: Inspect the cargo net restraint system. Heavy-duty nylon nets with quick-release fittings secure containers against the 9g forward load certification requirement.

components.name: Forward Cargo Door
components.description: The powered forward cargo door on the right side of the fuselage, providing access to the forward lower-deck cargo hold for LD3 container loading.
components.interactionText: Examine the powered forward cargo door. Hydraulic actuators open the large door upward, and a ball-mat transfer system inside guides containers into position.

components.name: Aft Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 containers in the aft cargo hold, the largest cargo compartment on the 777-200. This hold accommodates the majority of containerized baggage and freight.
components.interactionText: Examine the LD3 containers in the aft hold. The aft compartment is the largest on the aircraft, holding the majority of passenger baggage and cargo freight.

components.name: Aft Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: The cargo restraint system in the aft hold, securing containers and pallets during all phases of flight.
components.interactionText: Inspect the aft cargo restraint nets. The system must secure cargo against forces up to 9g forward, 1.5g sideward, and 2g upward.

components.name: Aft Cargo Door
components.description: The powered aft cargo door providing access to the rear lower-deck cargo hold. Located on the right side of the fuselage behind the wing.
components.interactionText: Examine the aft cargo door. Like the forward door, it opens upward with hydraulic assistance and has a powered drive system for container loading.

components.name: Bulk Cargo Loading Area
components.description: The bulk cargo compartment at the rear of the lower deck, used for loose-loaded baggage, mail, and small freight that does not require containerization.
components.interactionText: Examine the bulk cargo area. Loose baggage and mail are hand-loaded through a small door. A conveyor belt assists with loading irregularly shaped items.

components.name: Left GE90-94B Engine
components.description: The left General Electric GE90-94B turbofan produces 94,000 lbs of thrust. Its 128-inch fan diameter was the world's largest when introduced.
components.interactionText: Examine the massive GE90 engine. The 128-inch fan with 22 composite blades generates enormous thrust for transoceanic flight.

components.name: Right GE90-94B Engine
components.description: The right GE90-94B engine, identical to the left. The nacelle diameter of the GE90 is larger than the fuselage cross-section of a 737.
components.interactionText: The right GE90 nacelle is so large it could fit a 737 fuselage inside. The engine features a full-authority digital engine control (FADEC).

components.name: Nose Landing Gear Assembly
components.description: The 777 nose gear with dual wheels, larger and heavier-duty than narrow-body nose gear to support the aircraft's weight.
components.interactionText: The 777 nose gear is steerable and retracts forward. It is significantly larger than 737 nose gear.

components.name: Left Main Landing Gear
components.description: The left main gear is a six-wheel bogie with three axles, one of the largest landing gear assemblies in commercial aviation.
components.interactionText: Inspect the six-wheel bogie with carbon brakes on each wheel. The gear absorbs the impact of landing at weights up to 213,000 kg.

components.name: Right Main Landing Gear
components.description: The right main gear six-wheel bogie, identical to the left. Together they support the 777's maximum landing weight.
components.interactionText: The six-wheel configuration distributes the aircraft's weight for operation on a wide range of runway surfaces.

components.name: Left Aileron
components.description: The left outboard aileron, controlled by the fly-by-wire system. The 777 also has inboard flaperons that assist roll control.
components.interactionText: The fly-by-wire aileron is controlled by hydraulic actuators commanded by the Primary Flight Computers.

components.name: Right Aileron
components.description: The right outboard aileron, working in opposition to the left for roll control through the fly-by-wire system.
components.interactionText: The right aileron deflects opposite to the left, with authority automatically limited at high speeds by the flight computers.

components.name: Left Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: The left wing single-slotted Fowler flaps and inboard flaperon, providing high-lift capability for the 777's heavy weight operations.
components.interactionText: The 777 uses single-slotted Fowler flaps that extend on tracks, plus flaperons that combine flap and aileron functions.

components.name: Right Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: The right wing flaps and flaperon, deploying symmetrically with the left side.
components.interactionText: Watch the flaps extend rearward on tracks while the flaperon droops to augment lift.

components.name: Left Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the left wing, extending to increase the wing's maximum lift coefficient.
components.interactionText: The full-span slats extend from the wing leading edge, delaying stall and enabling lower approach speeds.

components.name: Right Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the right wing, operating symmetrically with the left side.
components.interactionText: The right slats deploy in concert with the left, maintaining symmetric lift generation.

components.name: Elevator
components.description: The fly-by-wire elevators on the horizontal stabilizer provide pitch control with envelope protection against excessive pitch attitudes.
components.interactionText: The fly-by-wire elevator includes envelope protection that prevents the pilot from exceeding safe pitch angles.

components.name: Rudder
components.description: The fly-by-wire rudder with speed-dependent authority limiting. Three independent hydraulic actuators provide redundancy.
components.interactionText: The 777 rudder has three hydraulic actuators and automatic authority reduction at higher speeds to prevent structural overload.

components.name: Wing Spoilers / Speed Brakes
components.description: Multiple spoiler panels per wing serve as speed brakes, ground spoilers, and roll control augmentation on the 777.
components.interactionText: The spoiler panels deploy symmetrically as speed brakes or differentially to augment roll control at all speeds.

components.name: Pitot Tubes
components.description: Multiple pitot probes on the forward fuselage measuring total air pressure for airspeed computation.
components.interactionText: The heated pitot probes provide airspeed data to the air data computers. Multiple probes ensure redundancy.

components.name: APU Exhaust
components.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU exhaust at the tail. The 777's APU is significantly more powerful than narrow-body APUs.
components.interactionText: The 331-500 APU provides 225 kVA of electrical power for ground operations and in-flight backup.

components.name: Weather Radar Antenna
components.description: The weather radar in the 777's large nose radome, providing long-range weather detection for transoceanic routes.
components.interactionText: The 777's weather radar has extended range for detecting weather hundreds of miles ahead on long-haul routes.

controlSurfaces.name: Ailerons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke turned left: left aileron up, right aileron down. Fly-by-wire computers modulate deflection based on airspeed.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Differential lift rolls the aircraft. The fly-by-wire system provides roll rate limiting and envelope protection to prevent excessive bank angles.

controlSurfaces.name: Elevator
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke pulled back: elevators deflect upward. Yoke pushed forward: elevators deflect downward. Fly-by-wire provides pitch rate control.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Elevator deflection commands pitch rate changes. The fly-by-wire system includes pitch envelope protection preventing stall and overspeed.

controlSurfaces.name: Rudder
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Left pedal pressed: rudder deflects left. Right pedal: rudder deflects right. Authority automatically limited at higher speeds.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Rudder yaws the aircraft. Speed-dependent authority limiting prevents structural damage from excessive sideslip at high speeds.

controlSurfaces.name: Trailing Edge Flaps
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flap lever positions: UP, 1, 5, 15, 20, 25, 30. Single-slotted Fowler flaps extend rearward and downward.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Flap extension increases wing camber and area for lower takeoff and landing speeds at the 777's higher weights.

controlSurfaces.name: Leading Edge Slats
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Slats deploy automatically with flap lever movement. Full-span deployment at landing configurations.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Slats increase maximum angle of attack before stall, critical for the 777's heavy-weight approach and landing performance.

controlSurfaces.name: Spoilers / Speed Brakes
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Speedbrake lever up: symmetric deployment. Roll input: asymmetric deployment augments ailerons.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Speed brakes increase drag for descent management. Ground spoilers deploy automatically on landing to dump lift and improve braking.

controlSurfaces.name: Flaperons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flaperons droop with flap extension and deflect differentially for roll control. Unique to the 777 design.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Flaperons combine flap and aileron functions, providing both high-lift augmentation and roll control in a single surface.
